doc.after: Nuffield was dismayed by the model of Harrison's plans, as the buildings were not in the general Oxford collegiate style that he was known to favour.[22] After a meeting with the University's Vice-Chancellor, A. D. Lindsay, Nuffield wrote to him on 15Â August 1939 to say that he felt "obliged to adhere to my adverse judgement of the plans".[1] The design was "un-English and out of keeping with the best tradition of Oxford architecture", said Nuffield, adding that "if a building of this type were to be erected, I would not allow my name to be associated therewith".[1]
